Description: Upper body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery closed vessel, possibly a stand; white slip; exterior: single black line at top; below, painted decoration consisting of goose (head and part of neck remaining), to right; elaborate rosette as filling ornament.
Producer name: Close to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl (according to Williams)
Attributed to: Group of the Würzburg Chalices (according to Lemos)
Curator's comments: Lemos places this sherd in the Würzburg Chalice Group. The sherds from this group display stylistic similarities to the two Würzburg chalices. Lemos identifies the sherd as belonging to a chalice, but it is quite thick for a chalice and unslipped on its interior. Williams prefers to see parallels with the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl and suggests that the sherd is closely related to the bowl. Furthermore, he believes the piece was painted by the same hand as British Museum 1888,0601.475.d, Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.48.1894 and GR.49.1894, probably also GR.50.1894.
The angle of the piece is a little off vertical, not clearly therefore from a neck or shoulder.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 71, p. 236 no. 154, pl.14)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p.128 fig.6, p. 132 note 27)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0001) (phase 2)
